DOC.HEAD: Governor Declares Florida a Disaster Area From Freeze
With PM-Frozen Profits, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Low-interest federal loans could be made available to Florida farmers who lost crops in the Christmas freeze after Gov. Bob Martinez declared the state a disaster area. Martinez sent a letter Thursday to U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yuetter asking for approval of the Farmers Home Administration loans. The governor also signed an executive order declaring the disaster following several visits to freeze-damaged farms. ``From what I have seen, there is no question that Florida has suffered devastating losses and that our state is a disaster area,'' Martinez said. ``We must now do everything we can to help those whose lives and livelihoods have been ravaged by the unmerciful weather.'' The governor's order affects all 67 Florida counties and opens the door to a possible disaster declaration by President Bush once the full extent of the losses is known. A presidential declaration would make unemployment assistance, direct grants and other assistance as well as FHA loans available to growers. The hard freeze Saturday and Sunday nights damaged Florida's 700,000-acre citrus belt as well as winter vegetable crops, many of which would have gone to markets in the Northeast. The state's tropical fish industry, sugar cane crops and plant nurseries also suffered heavy losses. Higher vegetable prices have already been reported, but the impact on citrus prices could be minimal because of a large juice reserve and the quick processing of frost-bitten fruit into concentrate. Reaction from growers was mixed, with some industry representatives saying the programs could throw the delicate supply-and-demand balance of the food business into disarray, driving down some prices. ``It can extend the disaster beyond its time,'' said Reggie Brown, spokesman for Florida Fruit and Vegetable Association in Orlando. Ernie Neff, spokesman for Florida Citrus Mutual in Lakeland, said not all growers could benefit from disaster programs, but they could keep some from going deeply into debt. ``When you're in a disaster area, you look for all the options. Not every grower can use them, but it will certainly help some,'' Neff said. State agriculture officials will assess the damage in each county to find the exact losses, which would be needed before a federal declaration is made. That could take two or three weeks. Jon Peck, the governor's press secretary, said it will take time to ascertain just how much of the citrus crop was lost because some damaged fruit can still be turned into concentrate for juice. Martinez earlier declared a statewide emergency that waived truck weight restrictions so growers can quickly haul their products to processing plants.
